Title.evidence: Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of High-Flow Nasal Oxygen in High-Risk Cardiac Surgical Patients

Trial_Design.evidence: In this single-centre trial, 100 adult patients undergoing elective cardiac surgery were randomised 1:1

Participants.evidence: Eligibility included COPD, asthma, recent lower respiratory tract infection, BMI ≥35 kg/m², or heavy smoking.

Intervention.evidence: randomised 1:1 to receive HFNO (n=51) or standard oxygen therapy (n=49)

Objective.evidence: This study evaluated whether high-flow nasal oxygen (HFNO) reduces hospital length of stay compared to standard oxygen therapy

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was hospital length of stay, measured from surgery to discharge.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated with allocation concealment via a centralised online system.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to surgical and nursing teams responsible for discharge decisions.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 100 adult patients undergoing elective cardiac surgery were randomised 1:1

Result_Outcome.evidence: Geometric mean hospital stay was 29% lower in the HFNO group (95% CI 11–44%, p=0.004).

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported.
